posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Hello, I’m new to Chief Delphi and I’m excited to be here. While I’m not entirely sure about the community’s customs, I’d appreciate any guidance on formalities or practices to follow. My team (6343) has been working with Python for a while and we’re considering a move to Java. I’d like to understand the potential benefits and challenges, as well as the key differences beyond syntax, to ensure a smooth transition. Thank you for your support!

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked:
I think a lot of the advantages of using Java in FIRST Robotics competitions stem from the strong community support. It is likely to be the easiest language to find example code, and copying code from top teams in previous years, who also predominantly use Java, will be straightforward. Additionally, getting assistance with code-related issues should be simpler since Java is one of the most widely recognized languages in FIRST competitions.

A new tool we found helpful this year was logging through Epilogue. Adding an annotation at the top of the class allows automatic logging of all relevant fields, significantly aiding in debugging efforts during the competition season.

To further develop your skills, consider rewriting this year's robot code in Java. This approach will provide a solid foundation for programming in future seasons. Good luck, and feel free to reach out with any questions!

link_counts.title: New for 2025: Robot Telemetry with Annotations (Java Only) — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Thank you for your input, especially on logging. We’re coming from AdvantageScope and I’ve heard of Advantage kit; do you know how that compares to Epilogue? Also, thank you for the idea of reprogramming our robot—I’ll probably bring that up to our mentor.

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: AdvantageKit requires significantly more setup work compared to Epilogue, offering benefits such as simulation replay, while Epilogue simplifies the process by only requiring a single line addition in each subsystem file.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: The text is: What would you say is your team’s experience level with Java? Do you have mentors or members with a solid background in it? Or are you all just learning?

posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Our main programming mentor is pretty much fluent in Java but is relatively new to robotics as this is his first year.

posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Would you say that the setup and different code structure is worth the benefits or is it something that is a side project in itself? And if we were all learning Java fresh, couldn’t we combine the input-output layers and the additional knowledge in the learning process?

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: We have not used advantagekit personally, and for our team this year, it wasn't worth it. Epilogue provided most of what we wanted, except for the lack of sim replay. Whether the additional features of advantagekit are worth it for you depends on your specific needs. I recommend watching the video recording of the 6328 champs presentation to help make that decision.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: There are some great resources to get started with "robot" programming, and having someone experienced with Java should make those pretty easy to follow. The off-season is definitely the right time to be looking into this; if you run into some unexpected trouble, you can always use Python for another year. Here’s one set of instructional videos: https://youtube.com/@0toauto?si=B1A6XaTu2SXUFav.

posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Alright sounds good, thank you so much for the input!

posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Oh, this looks really helpful! Thank you so much for your help!

posts.name: Dylan Li
posts.cooked:
1076 was in the same spot last year. Luckily, we documented our transition, from timed-based Python to command-based Java. Additionally, someone asked whether the setup and different code structure are worth the benefits or if it's something that could be considered an offseason project in itself. They also wondered if, when learning Java fresh, we couldn't couple the IO layers and other knowledge in the learning process.

For us, we started by converting the WPILib swerve template to be compatible with a REV drivetrain. Only after that did we move into adopting AdvantageKit. By doing this, you’ll ensure that you can learn the fundamentals of command-based programming and Java, making the adoption of AdvantageKit less of a jump. This does take a bit longer since you’ll have to write more code. We had a lot of time during school and in the offseason, but if you’re unable to spend as much time then you may find more success in splitting the transition into two years— one year for command-based programming and the next for AdvantageKit.

Hope this helps!

link_counts.title: FRC1076 - Switching to Java Notes - Google Docs

posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Thank you so much for the advice; this will be very helpful. We wish ourselves good luck for our transition.

Our team successfully transitioned from Java to Python this year, despite different experiences. Last year, while most programming students focused on the competition bot, two sophomore friends and I concentrated on perfecting swerve drive and later advanced to coding the comp bot entirely in Python. Many foundational principles from Java remained valuable, especially with the help of a senior experienced in Java, allowing us to streamline our processes smoothly.

posts.name: YehudaRothstein
posts.cooked: Java, unlike other programming languages, has much broader support for libraries such as WPILib and other types of programs and applications. Additionally, Java excels in object-oriented programming, which contributes significantly to command-based development and object-oriented programming in FIRST Robotics Competition, making it both easy and effective.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Python has a terrible lambda syntax, and no multiline lambdas.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: Definitely. It’s mostly not a problem though unless you’re using a framework that was designed around that paradigm, like commands.
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
EXTREMELY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLANATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH.  

Java, unlike other programming languages, has much broader support for libraries such as WPILib, and other sorts of programs and apps. In the FRC world, this is mostly true because vendors have become more important over time, and they mostly just support Java and mildly support other languages. Outside of FRC, it really depends. In addition, Java is really good with object-oriented programming, which contributes to command-based development and makes object-oriented programming in FRC easy and effective. Java/C++/Python can all be effectively used for object-oriented programming.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: In our robotics program, we transitioned from Java to Python to better align with our students' existing knowledge and skills. This switch allows us to focus on teaching programming concepts rather than the specifics of a particular language, which has proven beneficial for both students and mentors. Additionally, switching during the summer, when students have more time to prepare, is more effective than changing during build season. This approach minimizes new learning curves and helps maintain productivity.
